content.description: Just a few feet to the right of Upper Cannibal Left is a mixed line that guidebook author Dave Bingham describes as, "A pretty crummy route with two bolts."  Though the start is, indeed, a bit crumbly, if you happen to find yourself in that sector, this line is certainly worth a lap.  An easy, bouldery start gains access to a left-leaning crack.  Follow the crack to a bulge with a bolt, then past patina edges and a second bolt just below the chain anchor.
content.protection: Finger-sized cams protect the crack below the first bolt.

content.description: Though the Bingham guide describes the start of this route as a corner, we found that the more direct, bouldery start to the first bolt offered a more interesting alternative.  Fun face moves on good patina lead past the first bolt and to a stance--some good micro-cam placements can be found in a horizontal here, otherwise, the line takes on an "R" rating.  Boulder past the flaring, diagonalling seam to clip the second bolt; pulling the bulge then leads to easier ground, where one finds at least some gear before the chain anchors.
content.protection: Augment the two bolts with tips to finger-sized gear.

content.description:
A blocky crack ramble up the shorter wall that is upper Cannibal Corridor.

Wall used to be called "Hacker Wall" back in 2000 or so.
content.location: To the right of Upper Cannibal Right.

content.description: No secret here, the crux is off the ground moving through the first four or so bolts. A steep traverse leads to a couple power moves out of the roof section. The upper face is pure enjoyment moving over plates in the 5.9 range.
content.protection: 13 bolts to chains anchors, all well-spaced (as of 08/25/2018 the first 4 are spinners). Rappel to avoid rope drag.
content.location: Get Over It is the first route as you enter the corridor on your right. The line is visible form the  passing trail.

content.description: Start by slapping/heel hooking and then toe camming/knee barring your way up a big flake/rail for the first two bolts.  A rest leads into thin and strenuous climbing which stays hard until the last bolt.  Difficult clips off very small holds.
content.location: The bolted route just to the left of "Get Over It."
